Early Access Review

Stay away, simple as that.
The game itself after almost a year of development has gone basically nowhere. Same three bots since the begining, looting system is currently a chore to pick up anything that's inside a box/bag, game lags on lowest settings possible, in the dark sections of the game it's basically pitch black even on the highest brightness settings.

The Robots:

The Hunter is broken, always has been. In the begining it one shot you and could detect and walk through walls. One year later the only change is now it takes two shots to kill you. With how the damage system works the more damage you take the less mobility you have. One shot takes you from 100% down to 18% essentially crippling you. Leaving you to wait to die or take an hour to find a repair station to fix the damages. Personally I liked it better when they insta-killed me instead of me stuck there waiting to put the second bullet in me.

The Kamikaze bots are stupidly easy to deal with. They walk slowly, stand in place to explode, and take five seconds to explode. Making it insanely easy to just walk up to them to activate their self destruct and then casually walk away.

The Hives I don't know if they've been changed or not because I kept getting shot down by Hunters before I could get anywhere near one of their nests. They're insanely hard to shoot down and hack considering their high mobility.

Overall they can detect you before you even know they're there and you end up just getting gunned down.

Loot System/Items:

The loot system is rudimentary at best. picking up individual loose items is a breeze but picking up items in boxes or bags is time consuming and grating to grab items out of. Oh by the way the ammo comes in a box that you have to open first then take the ammo out of adding a needless step to looting. When grabbing items from a box/bag you have to click it then select the item then take an amount of said item. There is no double click to grab the whole stack or singular item. Items now no longer come in completed products. You now have to go out and find the seperate parts to craft said tools to do anything.

Weapons:

Melee weapons are a joke in single player. Good luck getting close enough to whack a Hunter to death, the Hive Drones are out of the question, and Why would you even?" with the Kamikaze bots. Guns now need to be built which is the only way to effectivly defend yourself against the Hunters and Hive Drones. So have fun hunting down every single part. Also you can't break down items into their base components or continue to craft on an incomplete item. Making anything you've finished crafting with only the parts you had effectivly useless.

Hacking:

Hacking is overcomplicated
date:
if you don't know coding before hand you're going to be referring to a guide before you memorize the basic commands (if you can even stomach playing that long).

Power/Mobility System:

I like the power system in this game
recommended: you need capacitors to store charged up power and you need reactors/solar panels to generate power. The more weight you carry the more energy you consume. If you run out of power you have to slowly waddle around or stand around a bit to generate some more power (unfortunatly you're not going to be able to stand around much). The jumping system sucks
hoursPlayed:
let's just sit here for two minutes while I charge up my jump to get over a two foot high ledge. Basically making jumping a chore and something to not bother with considering most of the map is flat anyway.

Optimization:

This game is terribly optimized. It lags on the lowest settings possible. The brightness setting literally doesn't even matter for it does basically nothing for the pitch black sections of the game.

After all of this my only advice is never buy this game or wait for another year to see if something significant has been done. After a almost a year in development this game has basically gone no where and it won't get anywhere fast. Just avoid the game and find something else to buy/play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*YES I AM AWARE THAT IT IS EARLY ACCESS - NOT FINISHED! IF YOU LIKE IT, KUDOS TO YOU. BUT NOTE I AM NOT YOU.*

I really tried to like this game, it felt like it could be something special even if it was really F-ing hard. But as the game is now, I can't play it without feeling increasingly frustrated at nearly every aspect of the game.
Yes, its a good game, it held on to me for almost a week, but my patience for it has ended, and I just can't play this anymore.

Pros:
- Crafting - Done in two ways, one by assembling tools & guns through your inventory screen (provided you have the parts), the other through some machine that cannot be moved or made (luckily there's more than one).

- Loot & Materials - All found in small flashing crates in almost areas. Most of the loot is pretty easy to find, but expect copies along the way. You can also, if you have the scematics, use the craft machine to recycle items in your inventory. And there's at least 3 Harvesters (that I'm aware of) that you can control & gather Wood, Ore, and Concrete for you.

- Jumping - Once you figure it out, you'll be able to jump at ridiculous heights, helps when you need to access an item & simply want a safe spot (I'll explain why in Cons).

- Building - As the trailer shows, you can build stuff. You can build pretty much anything in Wood, Concrete, or Brick. The Turrets however require a bit more to build & start up (but they are your base defenses with pretty epic range), and get their own drives.

Cons:
*Note - This is being developed by apparently one guy*

Bots (Enemies) - Every survival game wouldn't much of a challenge without enemies, but these enemies are relentless, annoying, and frustrating. Hunters (looks like Terminators with helmets) move a somewhat slow pace, but have ridiculous range, their mere presence WILL make you run for your life cause there won't be a viable way to fight them at start, and they can shoot you twice & you're dead. Suicide Bots will walk up to you and blow up (after having a seizure).

Bots Spawns - Random spawning is also understandable, but most times you'll as if the game intentionally TRYING to kill you as if you're the end of days or something. You can be walking along and then 1 foot away, an enemy spawns (sometimes you'll get a group).

Bugs - The bugs hurt the play experience a lot. Some enemies will clip on ladders then one second later they're back on the ground, then back at the top again. The menus during multiplayer will randomly stop working, making something simple become abyssmal level frustrating. Since the Hunters will war with the flying hive bots, you can expect some ridiculous lag. When building stuff, you can expect some decent lag, but the more you place & build, then more it goes from ok lag to WTF lag. And best of all, Bots can walk THROUGH WALLS that you built! Making your defensive walls pointless.

Building - Since the Dev tries pretty hard to add realism like gravity to the game, don't expect anything like Minecraft building in this game. If just one piece of your structure is even SLIGHTLY off, expect all your hard work to go to hell, and even better, you lose ALL of the used materials if the building falls. And it gets worse, sometimes you'll hit a point where the Auto-Placement will go where you don't want it, making custom projects almost impossible.

Multiplayer - Despite the game having 352 positive reviews, hardly ANYONE is online to play. Most people I've seen was 4 people in one room (including me). Most times though, the lag & menu bugs will increase rapidly while playing multiplayer (big bad for multiplayer only gamer types).

One Map - Thats right, just one map. The items' placement is random, but buildings, repair station, recycle machines, everythingelse in completely preset. And though there is a ridiculous huge tower out there, the point of it has not been discovered or explained - as that is, the huge tower is completely pointless & serves no other purpose than to take up space.

The Hunters always getting the drop on me, even while having a Radar was getting to me.
My health getting low forcing me to move slower than Yoda with a cane.
No real plot or story in the game.
But bots being able to walk through walls while being able to spawn in unfair spots, that pushed me over the edge.

Sorry to say, but you'll find less frustration in Dark Souls. I'm starting to regret even buying it...

Rating: 5/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was released in Early Access on 25 July 2014. It is currently still in Alpha and since the developer has never bothered to release a road map it's unknown if, or even when, it is supposed to progress beyond its present state.

Sadly it's now over 5 months since the last software update and the developer, Touz, continues to ignore the Steam community. A brief posting by him on January 6th was a rehash of previous statements he's made but did nothing to instill confidence that the game is moving forward in any significant way.

Current game play is, quite frankly, boring. At one time there were multiplayer servers that allowed for PVP but the online community has vanished.

The singleplayer component is bare-bones and has no goal. Essentially it consists of running around and attempting to find components for weapons and other bits and pieces while trying to avoid enemy AI. That's it. The weapon crafting system is needlessly complex and there is absolutely no reason to build a base as the AI is not programmed to recognize player structures.

The lack of any progression system, storyline or end goal severely limit replayability. This is made worse by the small static map that comprises the player world . Once all areas have been explored there is nothing to draw the player further into the game since there is no 'further' to be had.

If you are interested in this game, I'd suggest you wait. If the developer decides to actually work on the game and make significant improvements it may be worth purchasing at a future date. Right now it would be a waste of money.

Not recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's got potential but do realize it is early access and an alpha.  If you can't handle incomplete games with glitches and bugs -- look elsewhere.

Potential is nice - StarForge had mass potential and so have many other games.  Some reach it, others don't so go in knowing the risks and judge it based upon it's current state for playability -and- your willingness to risk based upon that potential.

A list of things to look at:
- The skill-point system only works multi-player so you won't skill up in single player.

- Multiplayer you will end up against leveled up oponents and those levels have meaning and high value.  Lots and lots of value to being leveled up here.

- Gathering requires hacking a harvester which then can take quite a while to gather things - you can't harvest anything.

- to get that hacking device you must find it.

- Robot NPC's drop nothing.  You need to hunt through ruins to find weapons, ammo and other supplies.

- ammo is fairly scarce for the quantity of robots you'll bump into - again, no points for dealing with AI opponents.  You're best bet is to run/aviod them.

- robots can pop up at any point near or far.  They have been toned down to 2 shots to kill you but that's the best you'll get.

- AI robots cannot aim upwards.  If you are above them, they can't hit you with their weapons -- if at range and above, they can and will hit you.

- AI robots can walk through walls that you build.  So if you build, make the building tall and use stairs to get up there.

- You need to find power for your unit - not those silly solar cells but nuclear power.  Without it, you won't be able to power up the capacitor to run, jump, etc.  Extra capacitors are good but you shouldn't need too many of them.

- picking up anything early will stop your running.  Anything except a nuclear power units.  The solar power cells weigh a ton for the energy they give, which slows you down.

- many items are sunk in the ground and other items - you'll see loot markers but can't loot the item nor even know what it is.

Again, it's got potential but that potential has a long way to go to be achieved.  IMO - worth supporting with funds but don't expect a highly clean and polished version at this time.

It runs well but it's not done yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first thing I noticed about TFD is that it looks much better than the majority of EAGames, especially this early in development. I spent a couple hours exploring the single-player world and was impressed with how good it looked, as well as how good the enemies and character models were.

Graphics aside, the gameplay is quite slow-paced at first. You'll spend the first few lives exploring around and learning the map. Since there's currently no in-game map feature at the moment, you'll have to use your compass and navigate by landmarks, like the tower, cities, and nuclear power plant. The hacking, which is necessary for any type of survival in the game, requires a tool that you don't start off with, so the first few minutes of every life will be spent searching for a hacking tool before too many enemy robots spawn. Once the tool is in hand, you can hack enemy hunters to make friendly guards that follow you around. I once had thirteen friendlies plodding their way behind me, shooting anything else that spawned around me before I got the chance to hack it and add to my army.
Oh, and you should avoid swarms like the plague. It's currently fantastically hard to hack a swarmbot, and they'll kill you and everything following you while you're trying.
Anyways, once you have a hacking tool, you need to find a harvester. These spawn in large dish-like structures in the ground, and they allow you to collect wood and other building materials for your base. Unless you know exactly where they are on the map, or unless you get wonderfully lucky and find a hacking tool right next to the harvester, you'll likely spend a good while searching for one before you can build a base, Once those resources start coming in, you've got the game won. Enemies can't currently shoot through doorways or windows, so you can build a square structure and hide in it until the end of day 5, or you can make a bunker with charging stations and turrets and only leave to scrounge up more resources that the harvester can't bring you, like ammo and capacitors.

All in all, it's a fantastic Alpha.

PROS--------
-Beautiful game
-Fun gameplay so far (if you enjoy exploration and the long-play style of Rust and 7 Days to Die)
-Loads of potential

CONS--------
-The updates are rather slow. Touz is currently the only dev on this game at the moment, and the updates are spread out. There was an update just a few hours before I posted this review, so it is still being worked on, but it takes a while.


This game is a fantastic early-access experience. If you like following early-access games, you'll love this.
I'd really love to see this game maintain the Robots gimmick instead of turning to Zombies, as many people have suggested in the forum. The market is already saturated with zombie crafting survival games, and even if it is a slight change, the robots and hacking and power supplies bring a refreshing change to the survival genre.

This dev does a great job and should be supported. This game is still extremely early in development, and is already fantastic. I love it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well,after readina lot of the reviews, I decided to give this game a go anyway.
So glad that I did.

The world is fairly open, insofar as it is a large worldbox. There's the ground, and hills, valleys, trees, buildings, tunnels, and the world extends out to the horizons in 4 directions (although you do hit the invisible wall at the edge).

There are no objectives per-se. You simply need to survive. You can collect resources (mainly via harvester dotted around the world that require hacking to activate and control). You play a drone robot, so power generation and consumption is everything. I found the fastest way was to collect solar panels from the farms and capacitors from various locations, then stand still for a while to charge before moving off.

Always keeping a watchful eye on the automated drones gives the game a certain edge, especially at night and when you're building structures. I build a small tower, and was standing at the top adding a roof when a drone walked into the bottom and exploded.
Needless to say, it took out a corner of the building and the whole thing fell down, but you take no damage from falling so dont die.
No, that comes in the form of hunter bots with shotguns that kill you in 2 shots.

Overall, in my opinion, a nice game. It contains elements I enjoy: survival, open world, freebuild of tools, weapons and structures, achievments (there are Steam ones as well as in game for solo and multi play), and most importantly, it's always recieving updates. Always small, but they are always fixing a bug or adding a new featre, which is great.

I bought The Fifth Day after watching one of PsiSyndicate's lets plays for it. He stated in his video that the game was poorly made, very buggy, and had little to no content. Still, I purchased it in hope of a half-way decent survival&building game.
Once I launched it I was greeted with a pleasant surprise. The game's visuals were beautiful and captured the asthetic of a cold, lonely wasteland well and without any FPS drops or crashing on maximum settings. Once I started walking around the desolate world I came across a new breed of enemy, robots. The bots were well modeled and effectively frightining, as one of them slowly turned around; scanned me and shot one round. Killing me in my place. I must say I jumped as the shot rang out.

Gameplay mechanics such and building and combat are fluid and difficult enough to provide a challenge, not a headache.
To start building you must find a hacker tool (They mainly spawn in cities and towns), and a harvester. (Harvesters are found in pits around the map) If you do find a harvester, you must hack into it using the tool mentioned above. Once hacked you command the machine to collect resources and drop them near you (The way the harvester flys around and drops supply pods is impressive for a game this young). Once you have enough resources you build using a recipe book found around the map. The building itself is rather alot like the game Rust" by Garry Newman
date: You craft templates and place them in a locking format. I prefer The Fifth Day's building more because it has no glitches with the terrain and more templates to produce more complex structures. Combat is wonderful
recommended: the weapon models sway with your charecter

I want to start by re-itterating what I said in a previous review for an early access game, I don't usually write reviews and I want to make it really clear that I am neither for nor against this particular game, it has positives and negatives like all games.

Now as far as early access goes, this game has stood up pretty well in my opinion, it looks very pretty (even on my crappy computer) and also on my friend much more powerful PC. The other little game additions like hacking, which I personally think is a fantastic idea, really makes the game feel that little bit more unique, and once you get the hang of it enemies become far less of a problem! Further positives are the way the game is playable, you choose to either go full frontal assault, or try to build up your defences first, or just loot and pillage like a stealthy ninja, entirely your choice and all completely plausible. A final positive is the loot drops, a lot of games try to do loot drops well and you end up either majorly disappointed or getting the same repetitive items that you have no use for, the drops aren't rare nor are they frequent, and that adds that realistic post apocalyptic feel.

Negatives now, enemies. reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Fifth Day looked very promising in the sense that it aimed to be a bit more than the average survival game. It isn't living up to that.
Lets start with CONS:
The AI ranges from absolutely horrendous to ridiculously overpowered. You can either run circles around a blind AI that won't do anything to you, or it'll phase a bot through a wall to kill you in a room you shouldn't have been killed in.
The overall survival ideology behind it is cool, but some of the systems therof (Namely the fact that as a robot, I shouldn't run out of energy from WALKING 20 feet when I have a nuclear reactor strapped to my back recharging capacitors.) are not at all fun. You can't walk 20 feet without getting winded, you can't find enough reactors to keep yourself charged, capacitors appear to do nothing but weigh you down unless you've found about 20 of those oh so elusive batteries.
The Loot Drops are probably one of the best and worst parts, which is why it's separating my Cons from Pros.
Reason why it's a Con:
Since it's hard for a ROBOT to walk 20 feet without getting winded, those batteries or Reactors shouldn't be so rare. They should be something that you find every 10 loot boxes. You find one every 120 loot boxes if you're lucky. This should be more balanced, or fix the recharge rate on those capacitors.
Why it's a Pro:
The loot drops are far enough apart to stop you from feeling instantly gratified, but are close enough together to keep you searching without making you feel hopeless. When you find one, the loot isn't always great, but it's never bad. There's always something useful in the boxes, or at least something that you feel could be useful later. (concrete? not early game, pal)
Another Pro to the game is the jumping mechanic. While I don't like that the default spacebar tap jump is less than I could do after a full pizza by myself, I enjoy the charge mechanic of jumping. The fact that I can jump over a tall building in a single bound is a great thing, and adds to the immensely enjoyable exploration of this game. Plus, the Dev rewards creative exploring, which is something that I admire.
The Hacking tool is something not found in your basic survival game, and for that I applaud The Fifth Day. I also bring a round of applause for the fact that the hacking isn't your average hold down the trigger or mouse click until it's complete
date:
mechanic. No, this mechanic makes you navigate systems with your keyboard, taking time, and making a hack harder to do in a pinch. If you wanna do it, it better be worth it. Great stuff.
The general ideology of the game with a post APOC robo world is an amazing idea. Keep rolling with that, keep with the art style in the spire.


Overall, I give this game a 5.5/10. The game is sub-par to say the least and had me raging within an hour of game play. I do believe the game can get better, and I hope to see much more out of it over time. Do I think you should buy this? Maybe. Buy it, put it in your Library, leave it there until it's more updated, or play it for feedback.
As it stands, the Pre Beta is not worth 14.00.

Do I recommend this game?
Yes.
Do I believe that you should wait for more updates?
Yes.

TLDR: more Cons than pros, but the game has a good enough idea, and a fairly active dev. recommend
5.5/10, Alpha test it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(NOTE: This review was made on an IPad. If it looks funky, that's why.)

So, for those of you who want a quick answer, yes, get this game. You will (most likely) not regret it.

Now for the more detailed analysis; this game, in its current state, is pretty dang fun. I've fiddled around with all the games major selling points and am pretty satisfied. For example, most survival games have guns that are pre-made and can't be modified aside from, for example, throwing a scope or silencer on it. TFD features weapons that can be modified and upgraded using gun parts you loot from the world. This makes acquiring a weapon pretty hard early on (though you can occasionally find an assembled weapon), but it also opens up many possibilities for your arsenal. Don't like the slide on your pistol? Simply switch it out with another, possibly better, slide. Want to decrease the weight of your weapon? Switch out the handle, shave off a little extra weight. And there's plenty more you can do with this, believe me. There is also a base construction system in place. It can be a little finicky at times, but all over all it's pretty easy to build yourself a structure, granted you get the resources to build it out of. Speaking of which, there is a hacking mechanic involved. I say this now because scattered around the map are harvesters that can be hacked to collect resources for you. Despite what other reviews are saying, it's incredibly easy to hack something. There is a bit of a command prompt, but all you need to do to hack a machine is to type in two commands; one right after the other. That's it. You can hack anything that moves (aside from players, of course). The enemies are particularly hard to deal with, but running away from them is a pretty easy thing to do until you have a gun and ammo. And looting, despite what people are saying, is relatively smooth. Not Rust smooth, mind you, but satisfactory none the less. The community is very small and the wiki is REALLY out of date, so you're going to be learning most of how to do things on your own. And the developers have not abandoned this game, they just released a bug-fix update not too long ago.

All over all, TFD is pretty worth the money. Yes, you're going to run into a bug or two; it's an alpha, it's going to do that. This is a hard game. My advice, save often and keep going. For those who enjoy a challenge, this should provide what you seek.

And the all-important rating: (drumroll) 9/10

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a survivial game set in a post apocalyptic setting where humanity has been wiped-out by machines.  You are an android and you must avoid or fight the robots that you encounter.

Although you do not require food or water to survivel (you're a machine) - you will need weapons, ammo and supplies.

There is an impressive home/base building system in this game.  You can build small shelters to massive installations (building system is similar to Rust).  The gathering of the building supplies is unique.  Instead of you" spending time collecting wood
hoursPlayed:
etc - you find and program flying machines called "Harvesters" to do this for you.

The enemy in this game are robots  that seek your destruction.  they come in a few different varieties.  One is a walking bomb.  Another is a flying swarm.  The other is essentially "Terminator".

You spend a lot  of your time exploring and searching through the ruined buildings for useful stuff - and you have to really manage your weight/energy supply in this game.  The more loot you carry - the more energy you use to move.  If you run out of energy - you must wait for your supply to recharge.  this becomes a problem if there are robots coming after you.  The enemies are a real threat - you can be one-shotted by them.

The most impressive part of this game is the structures you can build.  The downsize is that other than gun turrets and a power station - they are largely empty and only serve as protection against bots or other players (if play multi-player).  There really is no decorations or furniture - again you're a machine.

Overall in the short time I have played it - i like what I saw.  I think this game has potential.  The map is decent size but not massive.  I could not see multi-player supporting more than 3-4 players on a server.

And each time you do there is no drive behind it. This isn't fallout or far cry where trial and error are retty much rewarded (either with achievements, exp/$, or just your own reponsiveness to the game itself). This is a Bear Grylls see you later in the wilderness type ♥♥♥♥, cept its boring, the environment lackluster, with typical sound fx and NO MUSIC. Yeah...no music makes a dull open world even more boring.

Honestly wait to see what it becomes through dev video or fan devotion, otherwise spend your $ on something else.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Below you'll find both a video and written impression of the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gzTPWbnWit4
The Fifth day is another entry to the survival sandbox genre, but this time you're a robot. The game description state that it has craftable bases, hacking, AI, and other goodies, but after 3 hours of playing I saw none of that. After 3 hours I found 2 guns, a book, and some roboty things like power cells and... other kinds of power cells. I've read on the forums that there are some people who have built bases and done all the cool high end stuff this game claims to feature, but if I haven't seen a hint of any of that after 3 hours, I don't even want to fathom the dozens of hours it took those players to get to their point. Basically the game has serious pacing issues. The world though looks passable, is incredibly empty, with little to interact with.

The game does have some redeeming features. The visuals are passable, the concept of being a robot seems interesting, and I like the idea of all the features... too bad I didn't experience any of them.

Now I know this game is early access and because of that I may come back to this and revamp some of this written impression, but for the time being, The Fifth Day is, at it's best, a wait and see".

Pros:
- Passable graphic fidelity
- Interesting idea to feature robots as the playable characters
- The features sounds interesting (never experienced them though)

Cons:
- Terrible pacing
- Extremely obviously unfinished and unpolished
- At the moment

Welp lets start off by saying I never write reviews for games but having played every single survival game out there and having just about 600 hours on rust I can think I know enough about survival games that I can make a informative review. I was so hyped up for this just from watching the one trailer bought it as soon as I got home. I did the tutorial and jumped right into multiplayer cause thats where I have most of my fun. Played about an hour of the game 4-5 matches and I can say the only thing I found from walking to 4 different areas was 1 axe, a Glow stick type thing and a book to build a base. But only stopping to pick those things up. I spent the good 50 minutes of the hour I played walking. Not seeing a single other player. First second and third game I got 1 shot by an AI robot trying to go into maybe 3 of the 50 buildings i saw that you can actually go inside. Now on my last game I was being chased by a person or what I think was a person it was only me and him left and he followed me forever. Well i decided to sit and wait for him to come sure enough though I walk around the side of the building and one shot again. Now I wasn't sure if it was a real player or AI but one shot should no kill someone. Also you should be able to walk into all the buildings too loot stuff. Not just look at them like scenery. But the thing that annoys me most about this game is. I want to survive I want to fend for my life I want to find cool stuff on the ground and build a house to post up in. But that will never happen its Walking Simulator 2014 with the occasional angry one shotting AI.

In all essence the single player works very well but the multiplayer at its core is a great concept. Hell it's the hunger games with robots. But the way he has set up the multiplayer aspect of the game is poor. Poor doesn't even describe what multiplayer is. It's a nonfunctional walking wasteland. You will literally pay 15$ to walk. I mean walk for miles coming across every single building, busted up playground or crevice just to brough down by sadness that there is nothing around for you to use. But wait it gets better along that 30 minutes of walking you will encounter and AI that will follow you until you die. And guess what you have no way to defend youself because yes he does have a gun and of course you have no way  to defend yourself.

So as the game sits right now it is one word and one word only Trash. There are other survival games that got there ♥♥♥♥ together. I mean look at rust hundreds of bugs at it stat but you know what I was able to find guns and kill people. I could fend myself from all the animals and even when there were hackers I could kill them. But thje fifth day I feel like a walking useless punching bag

I look forward to seeing how this game is going to grow to it's final release.

I'm a fan of survival/crafting games, and I think this one is going to be great. I love the seting of being one of the machines left over after an apocalypse that killed all of humanity. It's a refreshing break from hordes of zombies, mutants, or aliens.

The Hunger/Thirst/Sanity mechanic common in other games in replaced with Power supply and consumption in The Fifth Day. Everything you do consumes power from your character's Capaticor stat. The rate of consumption depends on the action; walking consumes power quicker than stanging still, running quicker than walking, etc.. When your Capasitor stat reaches 0 you you stop being able to do anything. However, you also have a built in power generator which charges your capasitors when you are standing still. Located throughout the world are Power Stations where you can acquire more capasitors, remove them from yourself to quickly charge to full on the Power Station. I've also found solar power farms that I was able to recharge from.

A very cool feature I enjoy about the power consumption thing is that when you hold the space bar to jump you'll build up energy to apply for the jump to be higher. Very useful if you want to jump up to the top of a building to check for entrances or get a better view of the area. :)

The crafting system is easy to use, but I have dificulty finding the ingredients to make stuff so far.

I love being able to hack other machines, like Harvesters, to do my bidding. :) I wish that Harvesters would drop their payloads into one common container instead of littering the place with them.

Needs a larger map. I hate invisible walls. :(

One thing I hope the devs will change is how the player character looks. At the moment it looks like a human in a black suit with a silver faceplate. However, all the things that keep killing me are cool looking robots. I'm a leftover machine too. Why don't I look like a cool robot? Being able to find new parts to attach to myself and alter my looks and functions would be awesome. :)

I'm a fan of survival/crafting games, and I think this one is going to be great. I love the seting of being one of the machines left over after an apocalypse that killed all of humanity. It's a refreshing break from hordes of zombies, mutants, or aliens.

The Hunger/Thirst/Sanity mechanic common in other games in replaced with Power supply and consumption in The Fifth Day. Everything you do consumes power from your character's Capaticor stat. The rate of consumption depends on the action; walking consumes power quicker than stanging still, running quicker than walking, etc.. When your Capasitor stat reaches 0 you you stop being able to do anything. However, you also have a built in power generator which charges your capasitors when you are standing still. Located throughout the world are Power Stations where you can acquire more capasitors, remove them from yourself to quickly charge to full on the Power Station. I've also found solar power farms that I was able to recharge from.

A very cool feature I enjoy about the power consumption thing is that when you hold the space bar to jump you'll build up energy to apply for the jump to be higher. Very useful if you want to jump up to the top of a building to check for entrances or get a better view of the area. :)

The crafting system is easy to use, but I have dificulty finding the ingredients to make stuff so far.

I love being able to hack other machines, like Harvesters, to do my bidding. :) I wish that Harvesters would drop their payloads into one common container instead of littering the place with them.

Needs a larger map. I hate invisible walls. :(

One thing I hope the devs will change is how the player character looks. At the moment it looks like a human in a black suit with a silver faceplate. However, all the things that keep killing me are cool looking robots. I'm a leftover machine too. Why don't I look like a cool robot? Being able to find new parts to attach to myself and alter my looks and functions would be awesome. :)
